tariffs_v2.summary: Starting April 1, 2025, Moldova will export fruits such as grapes, apples, plums, and cherries to EFTA countries (Switzerland, Norway, Iceland, Liechtenstein) duty-free or with reduced tariffs, under the Free Trade Agreement signed in June 2023. This agreement aims to expand Moldova's trade partnerships and attract new investments.

articles.title: Moldova to export fruits duty-free to EFTA countries

tariffs_v2.summary: In February 2025, U.S. President Donald Trump announced new tariffs targeting Canada, Mexico, China, and the European Union. These tariffs are part of a broader strategy to match tax rates other countries charge on U.S. imports, contributing to macroeconomic uncertainty. The tariffs are expected to disrupt global supply chains, leading to inflation and increased recessionary risks. Affected industries include materials, industrials, consumer discretionary, and consumer staples, with specific impacts on products like live animals, vegetable products, prepared foodstuffs, base metals, machinery, and vehicles. The geopolitical and economic tensions are driving investors towards gold as a safe haven.

articles.title: A data-driven case for investing in gold in 2025

tariffs_v2.summary: In February 2025, US President Donald Trump announced new tariffs targeting key trading partners including Canada, Mexico, and China. The tariffs specifically impose a 25% rate on steel and a 10% rate on aluminum imports. This move is part of a broader strategy that includes a worldwide reciprocal tariff plan, raising concerns about a potential global trade war and its impact on struggling economies.

articles.title: US tariff policies causing concern in Vietnam

tariffs_v2.summary: President Donald Trump announced the re-imposition of tariffs on Mexico and Canada, set to take effect in early March 2025. These tariffs are expected to impact the American auto industry, which relies on long product cycles and significant investments in technology and new products. The tariffs could have significant economic implications for automakers and consumers in the United States.

articles.title: The auto industry, with 5-year product cycles, can't pivot on a dime to adapt to tariffs

tariffs_v2.summary: U.S. President Donald Trump has threatened to impose a 10% tariff on the 4 million barrels per day of Canadian crude oil imported into the U.S. This potential tariff has already caused a slowdown in Canada's oilfield drilling and services sector, with fears that it could stall the industry's expected rebound. The uncertainty surrounding the tariff has led to reduced forecasts for Canadian rig counts and downgrades of Canadian drilling stocks. There is also concern about possible retaliatory tariffs by Canada, which could affect inputs like sand used in fracking.

articles.title: Trump's tariffs threat hits Canada's oil and gas drillers

tariffs_v2.summary: The United States has increased tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles to 100% as of September 2024, under the Biden administration. This measure is part of a broader strategy to counter the perceived threat from Chinese EVs, which have captured a significant share of the global market. The tariffs are expected to impact the cost and competitiveness of Chinese EVs in the U.S. market.

articles.title: Chinese EVs Reshape Global Auto Industry Amid Tariffs

tariffs_v2.summary: In December 2024, Mexico announced a 19% tariff on all products imported from countries without a trade agreement, including China. This measure, implemented in January 2025, aims to protect the local textile industry from the impact of Chinese fast fashion. The tariff affects e-commerce platforms like Shein, Temu, and Alibaba, which have been selling inexpensive goods in Mexico. The policy is expected to encourage local manufacturing and address the loss of jobs in the textile sector. However, it also impacts millions of informal resellers who rely on these platforms for their livelihoods.
tariff_rates: 19% on all products from countries without a trade agreement

articles.title: Mexico's new tariffs hit Shein — and millions of local resellers

tariffs_v2.summary: The United States announced an increase in tariffs from 10% to 20% on Chinese imports in February 2025, closing a loophole for smaller imports. This move is part of ongoing trade tensions between the US and China, with potential impacts on US agricultural imports. China is considering both tariff and non-tariff measures in response.

tariffs_v2.summary: The United States, under President Trump, is threatening to impose new tariffs of up to 25% on goods imported from Canada and Mexico. This measure targets the automobile industry, affecting products such as automobiles, engines, and transmissions. The tariffs are expected to significantly increase costs for automakers like Nissan and Stellantis, who rely heavily on manufacturing in Mexico and Canada. The potential tariffs could add $1,000 to $4,000 to the price of a new vehicle, with broader economic impacts including job cuts and production shifts. Automakers are considering various strategies to mitigate the impact, including shifting production to other countries.

articles.title: 2 Troubled Carmakers, Nissan and Stellantis, Could Be Hit Hardest by Tariffs

tariffs_v2.summary: The United States, under President Trump, has announced a series of new tariffs targeting Canada and Mexico as part of a 'reciprocal tariffs' strategy. A 25% tariff will be imposed on all Canadian and Mexican imports starting March 4, with a reduced 10% duty on oil and gas. Additionally, a 25% tariff on global steel and aluminum, including Canadian products, will be implemented on March 12. Further tariffs include a 25% tariff on global auto imports, potentially escalating to 75% on Canadian cars by April 2. These measures are part of a broader strategy to address perceived unfair trade practices.
tariff_rates: 25% on all Canadian and Mexican imports

tariffs_v2.summary: In January 2025, the Nigerian Communications Commission (NCC) announced a 50% increase in telecom tariffs to ensure the sustainability of the industry amid inflation and foreign exchange volatility. The new rates, implemented on February 11, 2025, include NGN6 for SMS, NGN16.25 per minute for voice calls, and NGN525 for 1GB of data. The increase aims to address rising operational costs and maintain service quality. The NCC has mandated telcos to improve network quality and transparency in billing, with a three-month timeline for compliance.
